metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Role of catalysts in increasing reaction rates via alternative pathways of lower activation energy

catalyst_definition.name: Catalyst Definition
catalyst_definition.correct: A catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being consumed in the overall reaction. It participates in the reaction but is regenerated.

used up during the reaction.fix: Unlike reactants, catalysts return to their original form after the reaction.
used up during the reaction.action: Write the mechanism: catalyst enters, participates, then exits unchanged.

makes the reaction happen.error: Catalysts speed up reactions that would occur anyway.
makes the reaction happen.fix: Reactions can occur without catalysts, just more slowly.
makes the reaction happen.action: A catalyst makes a possible reaction faster, not an impossible reaction possible.

is a reactant.error: Reactants are consumed; catalysts are not.
is a reactant.fix: Catalysts participate but aren't in the overall equation as reactants or products.
is a reactant.action: Check the equation: catalysts appear on both sides or not at all.

persistent.action: Key test: Is it consumed? If no, it's a catalyst. If yes, it's a reactant.

alternative_pathway.name: Alternative Reaction Pathway
alternative_pathway.correct: A catalyst provides an alternative reaction pathway (mechanism) with a lower activation energy. The products formed are identical to the uncatalysed reaction.

the same pathway but faster.error: The pathway itself is different, not just faster.
the same pathway but faster.fix: Catalyst creates a new route with different intermediate steps.
the same pathway but faster.action: Compare: climbing over a mountain vs going through a tunnel. Different paths.

a pathway that produces different produc.error: Products are unchanged by a catalyst.
a pathway that produces different produc.fix: Same reactants, same products. Only the route (and speed) changes.
a pathway that produces different produc.action: Check: do catalysed and uncatalysed reactions give the same products? Yes.

a pathway that requires more energy.error: The alternative pathway requires LESS energy.
a pathway that requires more energy.fix: Lower Ea is the whole point‚Äîthat's why more particles can react.
a pathway that requires more energy.action: Draw energy profiles: catalysed path has a lower peak than uncatalysed.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what 'alternative pathway' means.
persistent.action: Draw both pathways: same start, same end, but catalysed path has lower peak.

activation_energy_lowering.name: Lowering Activation Energy
activation_energy_lowering.correct: A catalyst lowers the activation energy (Ea) required for a reaction. This means more particles have sufficient energy to react at any given temperature.

increases the activation energy.fix: Lower Ea = easier for particles to react = faster rate.
increases the activation energy.action: If Ea increased, fewer particles could react and rate would decrease.

doesn't affect activation energy.error: Lowering Ea is the primary function of a catalyst.
doesn't affect activation energy.fix: The whole mechanism is: lower Ea ‚Üí more successful collisions ‚Üí faster rate.
doesn't affect activation energy.action: Compare energy profiles with and without catalyst. The peak height differs.

eliminates the activation energy.fix: All reactions need some minimum energy. Catalysts reduce it but can't make it zero.
eliminates the activation energy.action: Even catalysed reactions have an Ea‚Äîjust a smaller one.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how Ea relates to reaction rate.
persistent.action: Link: Lower Ea ‚Üí more particles above threshold ‚Üí more successful collisions ‚Üí faster rate.

maxwell_boltzmann_catalyst.name: Catalyst Effect on Maxwell-Boltzmann
maxwell_boltzmann_catalyst.formula: Ea line moves left, not the curve
maxwell_boltzmann_catalyst.correct: On a Maxwell-Boltzmann diagram, a catalyst moves the Ea line to the LEFT (lower energy), so more particles exceed the activation energy. The distribution curve itself is unchanged.

shifts the curve to the right.error: That's what temperature does, not catalysts.
shifts the curve to the right.fix: Catalyst moves the Ea LINE left. Temperature shifts the CURVE right.
shifts the curve to the right.action: Catalyst: same curve, lower threshold. Temperature: different curve, same threshold.

makes the curve taller.error: Curve shape is unchanged by catalyst.
makes the curve taller.fix: Particle energy distribution depends on temperature, not catalyst.
makes the curve taller.action: The curve stays fixed; only the Ea marker moves.

increases the area under the curve.error: Total area = total particles, which is constant.
increases the area under the curve.fix: More particles are to the RIGHT of Ea, but total particles unchanged.
increases the area under the curve.action: Shade the area right of Ea: this area increases when Ea moves left.

persistent.gap: You're confusing catalyst and temperature effects on Maxwell-Boltzmann.
persistent.action: Make a comparison: catalyst moves Ea left; temperature shifts curve right. Both increase rate.

enthalpy_unchanged.name: Enthalpy Change Unchanged
enthalpy_unchanged.correct: A catalyst does NOT change the enthalpy change (ŒîH) of a reaction. The overall energy difference between reactants and products remains the same.

makes the reaction more exothermic.error: ŒîH is unchanged by a catalyst.
makes the reaction more exothermic.fix: Start and end points are the same. Only the path between them changes.
makes the reaction more exothermic.action: On an energy profile: reactant and product levels stay fixed.

makes the reaction less endothermic.error: ŒîH is a state function‚Äîit doesn't depend on pathway.
makes the reaction less endothermic.fix: Whether catalysed or not, ŒîH = Hproducts ‚àí Hreactants.
makes the reaction less endothermic.action: Same reactants, same products, same energy difference = same ŒîH.

increases the energy released.error: Energy released depends on ŒîH, which is unchanged.
increases the energy released.fix: Catalyst changes the RATE, not the ENERGETICS.
increases the energy released.action: Burning petrol releases the same energy with or without a catalyst.

persistent.gap: You're confusing activation energy with enthalpy change.
persistent.action: Draw an energy profile. Ea = peak height above reactants. ŒîH = difference between reactant and product levels.

equilibrium_unchanged.name: Equilibrium Position Unchanged
equilibrium_unchanged.correct: A catalyst speeds up BOTH forward and reverse reactions equally. Therefore, it does NOT change the equilibrium constant K or the position of equilibrium‚Äîonly the rate of reaching equilibrium.

shifts equilibrium to the right.fix: Both directions speed up equally, so the ratio of products to reactants stays the same.
shifts equilibrium to the right.action: If forward rate doubles, reverse rate also doubles. Net effect on position: none.

increases the equilibrium constant.error: K depends only on temperature, not catalysts.
increases the equilibrium constant.fix: K = [products]/[reactants] at equilibrium. Catalyst doesn't change these concentrations.
increases the equilibrium constant.action: Only temperature changes K. Catalyst, concentration, pressure don't.

only speeds up the forward reaction.fix: The catalyst lowers Ea for both forward AND reverse reactions.
only speeds up the forward reaction.action: Same catalyst, same pathway, same lowering of Ea‚Äîfor both directions.

persistent.gap: You think catalysts favour one direction over the other.
persistent.action: Remember: catalyst speeds up reaching equilibrium, doesn't change where equilibrium lies.

homogeneous_catalyst.name: Homogeneous Catalyst
homogeneous_catalyst.correct: A homogeneous catalyst is in the SAME phase as the reactants. For example, an aqueous catalyst with aqueous reactants, or a gas-phase catalyst with gaseous reactants.

different phase from reactants.fix: Homo = same. Homogeneous catalyst = same phase as reactants.
different phase from reactants.action: Acid catalyst in aqueous solution = homogeneous (both aqueous).

only works with liquids.error: Homogeneous applies to any phase, as long as catalyst and reactants match.
only works with liquids.fix: Gas + gas catalyst = homogeneous. Liquid + liquid catalyst = homogeneous.
only works with liquids.action: The key is matching phases, not a specific phase.

means only one catalyst is used.fix: Homogeneous = same phase. It's about WHERE the catalyst is, not HOW MANY.
means only one catalyst is used.action: You can have multiple homogeneous catalysts in the same phase.

persistent.gap: You're misinterpreting 'homogeneous' in the catalyst context.
persistent.action: Homo = same. Homogeneous catalyst = same phase as reactants. Simple.

heterogeneous_catalyst.name: Heterogeneous Catalyst
heterogeneous_catalyst.correct: A heterogeneous catalyst is in a DIFFERENT phase from the reactants. Commonly, a solid catalyst with liquid or gaseous reactants. Reactions occur at the catalyst surface.

same phase as reactants.fix: Hetero = different. Heterogeneous catalyst = different phase from reactants.
same phase as reactants.action: Solid platinum with gas reactants = heterogeneous.

mixed with the products.error: Heterogeneous refers to phase difference, not mixing with products.
mixed with the products.fix: The catalyst is in a different phase‚Äîthis makes it easy to separate after reaction.
mixed with the products.action: Solid catalyst can be filtered from liquid products.

only works with solids.error: It's about the DIFFERENCE in phase, not being solid specifically.
only works with solids.fix: Solid + gas = heterogeneous. Solid + liquid = heterogeneous. The solid is just common.
only works with solids.action: In principle, liquid catalyst + gas reactants would also be heterogeneous.

persistent.gap: You're confusing homogeneous and heterogeneous definitions.
persistent.action: Hetero = different. Different phase from reactants. Usually solid with liquid/gas.

surface_catalysis.name: Surface Catalysis
surface_catalysis.correct: In heterogeneous catalysis, reactants adsorb onto the catalyst surface, react, and products desorb. The surface provides active sites where reactions occur.

reactants dissolve into the catalyst.error: Adsorption is surface binding, not dissolving throughout.
reactants dissolve into the catalyst.fix: Adsorption = sticking to surface. Absorption = dissolving into bulk.
reactants dissolve into the catalyst.action: Molecules stick to the surface, react there, then leave. They don't enter the catalyst.

only the catalyst surface area matters.error: Surface area affects rate, but active sites and mechanism also matter.
only the catalyst surface area matters.fix: More surface area = more active sites = faster rate. But catalyst chemistry matters too.
only the catalyst surface area matters.action: Powdered catalyst reacts faster than a lump of the same catalyst.

products form inside the catalyst.error: Reaction occurs on the surface, not inside.
products form inside the catalyst.fix: Adsorb ‚Üí react at surface ‚Üí desorb. All surface processes.
products form inside the catalyst.action: Think of the surface as the 'reaction zone' for heterogeneous catalysis.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the adsorption-reaction-desorption mechanism.
persistent.action: Draw: reactant approaches ‚Üí sticks to surface ‚Üí reacts ‚Üí product leaves surface.

biological_catalysts.name: Biological Catalysts (Enzymes)
biological_catalysts.correct: Enzymes are biological catalysts‚Äîproteins that speed up biochemical reactions by lowering activation energy. They are highly specific to their substrates.

work differently from chemical catalysts.error: Same principle: lower Ea, not consumed, same products.
work differently from chemical catalysts.fix: Enzymes and industrial catalysts both lower Ea via alternative pathways.
work differently from chemical catalysts.action: The mechanism differs, but the outcome is the same: faster reaction.

are consumed in reactions.error: Like all catalysts, enzymes are regenerated.
are consumed in reactions.fix: Enzyme binds substrate ‚Üí reaction occurs ‚Üí products released ‚Üí enzyme free again.
are consumed in reactions.action: One enzyme molecule can catalyse millions of reactions.

work at any temperature.fix: Enzymes have optimal temperature ranges. Too hot = denaturation = loss of activity.
work at any temperature.action: This is a key difference from many industrial catalysts that work at high temperatures.

persistent.gap: You don't see enzymes as catalysts following the same principles.
persistent.action: Compare: both lower Ea, both regenerated, both speed up reactions. Enzymes are just biological.

catalyst_definition.title: What is a Catalyst?
catalyst_definition.content: A catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being consumed in the overall reaction. It participates in the reaction mechanism but is regenerated, allowing it to be used repeatedly.

alternative_pathway.title: Alternative Reaction Pathway
alternative_pathway.content: Catalysts provide a different reaction mechanism‚Äîan alternative pathway‚Äîthat has a lower activation energy than the uncatalysed reaction. The products formed are identical; only the route taken is different.

activation_energy_lowering.title: Lowering Activation Energy
activation_energy_lowering.content: The primary function of a catalyst is to lower the activation energy (Ea) required for a reaction. This means more particles have sufficient energy to react at any given temperature, increasing the reaction rate.
keyPoints: More particles exceed the lower Ea

maxwell_boltzmann_catalyst.title: Catalyst Effect on Maxwell-Boltzmann Distribution
maxwell_boltzmann_catalyst.content: On a Maxwell-Boltzmann diagram, a catalyst moves the Ea line to the left (lower energy), increasing the proportion of particles that exceed the activation energy. The distribution curve itself is unchanged‚Äîthat depends on temperature.
keyPoints: Different from temperature effect (which shifts curve)

enthalpy_unchanged.title: Enthalpy Change is Unchanged
enthalpy_unchanged.content: A catalyst does not change the enthalpy change (ŒîH) of a reaction. Since the reactants and products are the same, the overall energy difference between them remains unchanged. Only the pathway between them is different.
keyPoints: Same reactants and products = same ŒîH
Only the pathway changes, not start/end energies
Ea changes but ŒîH does not

equilibrium_unchanged.title: Equilibrium Position Unchanged
equilibrium_unchanged.content: A catalyst speeds up both forward and reverse reactions equally by lowering Ea for both directions. Therefore, it does not change the equilibrium constant K or the position of equilibrium‚Äîonly how fast equilibrium is reached.

homogeneous_catalyst.title: Homogeneous Catalysts
homogeneous_catalyst.content: A homogeneous catalyst is in the same phase as the reactants. For example, an acid catalyst dissolved in an aqueous reaction mixture. Homogeneous catalysts can be harder to separate from products after the reaction.
keyPoints: Example: aqueous catalyst with aqueous reactants

heterogeneous_catalyst.title: Heterogeneous Catalysts
heterogeneous_catalyst.content: A heterogeneous catalyst is in a different phase from the reactants, commonly a solid catalyst with liquid or gaseous reactants. Reactions occur at the catalyst surface. These are easier to separate from products.
keyPoints: Commonly solid catalyst with liquid/gas reactants

surface_catalysis.title: Surface Catalysis Mechanism
surface_catalysis.content: In heterogeneous catalysis, reactant molecules adsorb onto the catalyst surface at active sites, react there, and products then desorb. The surface area and number of active sites affect catalyst effectiveness.
keyPoints: Reactions occur at active sites on surface
Powdered catalysts have more surface area

biological_catalysts.title: Biological Catalysts (Enzymes)
biological_catalysts.content: Enzymes are biological catalysts‚Äîproteins that speed up biochemical reactions. They work by the same principle as other catalysts (lowering Ea) but are highly specific to their substrates and sensitive to temperature and pH.
keyPoints: Lower activation energy like all catalysts
Sensitive to temperature and pH (can denature)
